div.head: Real-world use cases and commercial/open-source products
div.p: This section aims to provide the applications of traffic classification for IoT. We refer to the applications of IoT traffic classification to the available real-world use cases and products. It outlines several commercial/open source and free cybersecurity solutions available today for IoT use. Despite the wide usage of traffic classification solutions, current products mainly address the security perspective of IoT. The current products are mostly developed for professional use and may not explicitly aim at the IoT environment. However, there are few commercial products that are claimed to be solely designed for IoT/smart home cybersecurity. In this section, we provide cybersecurity products that are available as commercial and non-commercial IDS/IPS applications.

div.head: Traffic-based analysis
div.p: There are several open-source and free cybersecurity solutions based on network traffic analysis that are freely available. Snort [120] is an open-source IDS/IPS that is developed and owned by Cisco System. It is based on wellknown tcpdump that sniff traffic for real-time network analysis and logging. This application is based on pattern matching detection. A packet in the network traffic is analyzed by a packet decoder module by which various features of the packet such as a data-link layer, network protocols, and TCP or a UDP segment are examined. The results from the analysis are then forwarded to a pre-processor module in which the IP packets are edited or discarded. At the final stages, Snort compares the received data from the pre-processor with the rules containing the footprints from attacks of different layers of the OSI model [121]. Similar to Snort, Suricata [122] is an open-source and free IDS/IPS that is based on pattern matching detection in real-time. This project was designed and developed by the Open Information Security Foundation (OISF). In Suricata, all the information is collected from the application layer and merged. The merged information is sent for analysis in the final stage. It is also able to evaluate the activities in the protocol level at the lower levels of the OSI model such as IP, TLS, ICMP, TCP, and UDP. Bro [88] is a NIDS, based on Unix systems. It is designed and developed in the Lawrence Berkeley National Labs and the International Computer Science Institute. Bro NIDS detects intrusions using pattern recognition in the network traffic. To monitor the traffic of inbound and outbound in a real-time manner, this application employs two network interface cards. In addition, to minimize the CPU load in FreeBSD, it proposes using patched kernel modules. Bro claims the speed of real-time detection up to Gbps. OpenWIPS-ng [123] is an open source and free modular Wireless IPS (Intrusion Prevention System) that protects wireless passwords based on packet sniffing by detecting intrusion patterns

div.head: Log-based analysis
div.p: Log-based threat analysis usually works based on reading the log files that have already been produced via a trafficbased analysis tool. Therefore, log-based analysis products are often faster than those products whose analysis is based on network traffic. However, a real-time detection feature is omitted in these products due to their nature as the detection process is accomplished after the log files are created. Open Source HIDS Security (OSSEC) [124] is an open-source and free HIDS designed and developed by Trend Micro. Although OSSEC is unable to analyse network data traffic, it provides an evaluation of the checksum signatures of all log files to detect possible intrusions. Sagan [125] is an open-source and free HIDS based on log analysis. Segan is also compatible with the data gathered by Snort. AIDE (Advanced Intrusion Detection Environment) [126] is a Unix-based open source and free HIDS that works based on signature comparison and focuses on the detection of rootkits. It works based on creating databases from config files and then verifies the integrity of the files based on the regular file expression in its datasets. Samhain [127] is an opensource and free HIDS that offers evaluation/analysis of file integrity, and log files as well as detecting rootkit viruses by using log file analysis.

div.head: IoT commercial cybersecurity solutions
div.p: There are several commercial cybersecurity solutions available to date for home-scale IoT devices. Norton Internet Security [128] introduces Norton Core which is an in-home Wi-Fi router that uses deep packet inspection for intrusion detection, and Symantec Global Intelligence Network (GIN) to secure IoT devices. A security score is calculated for every connected device in the network to set the level of security threats and action to be taken. On the other hand, BitDefender BOX hub [129] provides a smart home cybersecurity solution with several features such as device identification and management, vulnerability assessment, anomaly detection and security protection against brute force. It also provides an enhanced parental control that safeguards the user from cyberbullying and scams. It can also send alerts for any verbal attacks, aggressive language, an inappropriate invitation or requests for private information such as pictures, passwords, and card numbers. CUJO [130] is another popular AI-driven cybersecurity and network intelligence solution that gives an auto device identification that recognizes names, brands and group devices on the home network. It goes through an identification phase by organising information into several levels where each level uncovers additional details on the network device (i.e. Apple product to Apple TV to Apple TV 4K). Furthermore, it supports personalized security for every device in and out of home by proactively blocking new and known threats. Following the trend, Dojo Intelligent Platform (DIP) [131] is a multi-layered IoT cybersecurity solution for home and communication service provider that provides IP packets analysis as they arrive through a Wi-Fi router. Dojo's sophisticated defence system utilizes pattern recognition to learn to protect the Wi-Fi network and all the smart connected devices from intruders and cyber risks. DIP offers three major features for service providers, which are, the gateway solution, the cloud-based platform, and the mobile app SDK. Whereas Luma [132] suggest that the smart Wi-Fi router provides a simple set up and deployment. In addition to its cybersecurity protection that blocks hackers from accessing a network and providing alerts on a potential threat, it gives a performance boost by prioritizing devices when it is necessary. Luma focuses on privacy connection with an advanced encryption, VPN network over thousands of servers in scattered locations, and a shared IP address to keep an activity untracked. Another popular antivirus, F-Secure introduced F-Secure SENSE router [133] that comes as part of the total premium cybersecurity package, which also includes internet security, VPN, and a password manager for all connected devices. Uniquely F-Secure SENSE uses computing power to scan files from malware and running analysis through AI approaches on file metadata and performs further analysis on the steps or classifies the object as clean/malicious. As a privacy principle, it ensures to collect only needed data while respect the users' privacy. It also uses device discovery to adapt to its security needs, as different types of connected devices require different types of protection. Then, with the whole devices topology in view, the security engine monitors and alerts when any abnormality takes place in smart devices, by sensing their traffic to provide extra protection against IoT threats.

div.head: Available Datasets for IoT
div.p: The effectiveness and reliability of researches are evaluated based on their performance. For example, in the case of an IDS, the effectiveness is evaluated by the detection of attacks. This evaluation requires a comprehensive dataset that contains normal and abnormal behaviours. As such, the quality of the dataset plays a big role in the development phase as well as in the implementation phase. As the network behaviours and patterns change, a perfect dataset could provide an effective model to the detection model in a real threat environment. Improvement in dataset collection may assist in improving cybersecurity research throughout the time. Today, a number of public datasets are available for testing and evaluation in the cybersecurity research area. In [134] a taxonomy of different datasets related to the cybersecurity area was discussed. Based on this taxonomy, current datasets are categorized into three main groups which are synthetic, benchmark, and real-life datasets.

According to [135], synthetic datasets are generated to address particular demands, conditions or evaluations that satisfy real data. They are effective in designing any type of system for theoretical analysis so that the design can be augmented. Synthetic datasets help to discover a primary solution or remedy when the outcomes prove to be satisfactory. They are utilized in testing and designing various types of test scenarios.
Benchmark datasets are generated using simulated environments in large networks. The simulation of different attack scenarios is performed during the generation of benchmark datasets.

Real Life datasets are created by collecting network traffic in a specific period of time on a realistic network. They comprise both normal as well as attack traffic in appropriate proportions (i.e., testbeds). Figure 4 shows a taxonomy of different datasets that are used in IoT network traffic classification. Many studies reviewed in this paper have proposed their evaluation through a testbed in which the datasets used are private. In this section, we present well-known public datasets that were applied to the reviewed research works. Table 5 shows available datasets along with their technical details.
div.formula: • Cridex • Geodo • Htbot • Miuref • Neris • Nsis-ay • Shifu • Tinba • Virut • Zeus
div.p: A total number of 752,040 records.
From a real network traffic in two part.

7.1.1 KDDCup99 [136] The most widely used datasets for the evaluation of network-based anomaly detection methods, developed in 1999 upon the data captured in the DARPA98 IDS [138] evaluation program. KDDCup99 compromises a training dataset consists of 4,900,000 connections vectors from which normal and attack traffic are labelled in 41 features. The training set includes 24 different attack types. Also, the test dataset consists of 300,000 samples with a total 24 training types. The categories of attacks include denial of service, remote-to-local, user-to-root, and surveillance or prob.

However, due to the imbalance test and training data of KDDCup, it shows a poor performance for the evaluated system. The work in [139] introduced the NSLKDD dataset to overcome the KDDCup dataset weakness. They improved the KDD dataset in these aspects; non-repeated and duplicate record to remove bias towards data frequency, resampling the number of selected records from each difficulty-level to address the skewed and unproportioned distributed issues. However, according to [139,140], a major disadvantage of NSLKDD is that the low footprint attack scenarios were neglected to be represented. 7.1.2 ISCX-UNB [141] The ISCX-UNB dataset is created based on the concept of profiles that include detailed descriptions of intrusions and abstract distribution models for applications, protocols, or lower-level network entities [142]. It was captured in an emulated network over five (5) days. It utilizes two different profiles (α-profiles and β-profiles) to create a new dataset in packet-based and bidirectional flow-based format. The α-profiles describe the malicious activity and β-profiles define normal user behaviour that generated from the real activity of a traffic network. The packets are labelled network traces, including full packet payloads in pcap format. The dataset consists of attacks including Brute Force FTP, Brute Force SSH, DoS, Heartbleed, Web Attack, Infiltration, Botnet and DDoS.

div.head: UNSW-NB15 [137]
div.p: The UNSW-NB15 was generated by the IXIA PerfectStorm tool in the Cyber Range Lab of the Australian Centre. The dataset consists of 100 GB of raw network traffic in pcap files using tcpdump tool. It consists of 2,540,044 records divided into several pcap files for easier analysis, each of the size of 1 GB. The dataset comprises extraction of modern normal attacks coupled with the contemporary attack activities of network traffic. The training part of the dataset comprises 175,341 records, and the testing set involved 82,332 records. Both the training and testing sets consist of attack types and normal records [137] [143]. Nine types of attacks and six groups of features are presented in UNSW-NB15 [137] [144]. The attack's types include Fuzzers, Analysis, Backdoors, DoS, Exploits, Generic, Reconnaissance, Shellcode and Worms.

div.head: N-BaIoT [87]
div.p: N-BaIoT provides a public botnet dataset in IoT network traffic. The dataset contains a total number of 7,062,606 records from the real-world data traffic that is compromised by malicious data divided into ten (10) attacks carried by (2) botnets namely Mirai and BASHLITE botnet collected from nine (9) commercial IoT devices via Wi-Fi to several access points. The types of BASHLITE in the dataset are Scan, junk, Flooding (TCP/UDP), and COMBO. Also, Mirai attacks comprises Scan, Ack, Syn, UDP Flooding, and UDP Plain. Wireshark [85] was used to record the traffic of the sniffed routers that are connected to the Wi-Fi access points. 7.1.5 Network dataset from an IoT system with MQTT protocol attacks [63] [86] The data recorded in this dataset has been collected from several sensors, actuators, and a server in a lab environment. The dataset consists of three files each of which comprises one type of attack; (i) DoS file which involves 45,513 records that under attack traffic and 49,112 ones which are normal traffic, (ii) Man in the middle (MitM), comprises 3,855 records under MitM and 106,813 normal traffic frames, and (iii) Intrusion, represents 801,898 records under attack and 78,995 are normal traffic frames [63].

7.1.6 AWID [145] Aegean WiFi Intrusion Dataset (AWID) is a dataset that contains a data-trace from a dedicated WEP protected 802.11 network traffic from an emulated SOHO network in a physical lab [146] that consists of both normal and intrusive traffic. Two sets of records were collected for training and testing purposes. The size of the whole dataset is 935 MB containing 1,795,575 records, out of which 1,633,190 records presents normal traffic and 162,385 records are classified as intrusive. The traffic was collected during one hour with the attack traffic period lasting for 15 minutes. The number of attack records in the training and testing sets is 162385 and 44858 respectively. There are three (3) major classes of attacks namely Flooding, impersonation, and Injection. 7.1.7 UTSC-2016 [118] The UTSC-2016 dataset was created from two parts in which the first part consists a collection of malware traffics collected from a real-world network trace between 2011 and 2015 by CTU researchers [147]. The malware traffic consists of a total of ten types namely Cridex, Geodo, Htbot, Miuref, Neris, Nsis-ay, Shifu, Tinba, Virut, and Zeus. The second part consists of ten types of normal traffic collected from network traffic simulation using IXIA BPS [148]. The total size of USTC-TFC2016 is 3.71GB in pcap file. UTSC-2016 comprises a total record of 752,040 in which malware and benign traffics have a total count of 406,633, and 345,407 respectively.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: There are a number of intrusion detection models that have been built and developed for the purpose of research and development that contribute to features enhancement as well as intrusion detection. Similarly, countless detection approaches were proposed to advance the effectiveness of the detection models. Previous works demonstrate the important role of datasets in IDS research community. Nevertheless, some discussion on the benchmark dataset determines their ineffectiveness to replicate the real traffic environment [135] due to; (i) most of the datasets are improperly labelled or are unlabelled as the information of the actual attacks is unknown, (ii) unbalanced proportion of data instances (benign and malicious) [149], [135], (iii) inadequately trained or updated data from recent network traffic. On the other hand, there are several challenges in real-life datasets for IoT apart from the challenges in collecting real-time network traffic with a comprehensive labelling [150]. The other challenges include problems with anonymized data that related to data privacy [151], lack of relevant traffic features [152], and difficulty in satisfying the requirement for different types of IDS (host-based and network-based) [135].

div.head: Challenges and Open issues
div.p: Recently, IoT traffic classification has been targeted by the academic community due to its capabilities to analyse and infer the network traffic. However, because this field of research is still in the early stage, it will encounter several challenges and open research issues. The concept of traffic classification is identical in IoT and Non-IoT domains by which network traffic is analysed for different purposes. To date, there are a number of published works such as [4], and [92] on open research challenges and direction on solely traffic classification and hence, in this section we discuss more on recent challenges and issues in the applications and enabling technologies of IoT traffic classification. This section presents several challenges as well as open research issues for IoT traffic classification.

div.head: Challenges
div.p: Traffic classification in IoT faces a number of challenges such as quality of service, infrastructure, standardisation, and data source. These challenges must be fully addressed in IoT in order to be deployed as a concrete solution. Most of the IoT devices are wireless from which different traffic models are generated. Security breaches must be carefully analysed by studying valid and up-to-date datasets. Different environments and infrastructures require specific studies and analyses. These are seen as extremely challenging issues due to the heterogeneous nature of IoT.

div.head: Quality of service (QoS)
div.p: With a sharp increase of latency-sensitive services and applications in IoT domain, a demand for higher speed transmission is required on the Internet. Based on an analytic report from the Cisco Visual Networking Index 2017-2022 [153], the monthly volume of the world's Internet traffic exceeds 200 and 396 exabytes in 2019 and 2022 respectively. Similarly, the estimated volume of video/voice traffic in 2019 and 2022 will reach 77%, and 82% of the total Internet traffic respectively. To meet the traffic demands of such huge volumes, an efficient use of the available resources such as bandwidth, frequency slot of an Elastic Optical Network (EON), and memory capacity of a datacentre are of a high importance. It is reported that improper treatment of network traffic effectively impacts the survivability of the network and the QoS requirements [154]. IoT is tightly coupled with the Internet and their traffic go through the same medium. Meeting QoS requirements guarantee the services and applications continue serving. Network Traffic Classification is a significant component for infrastructure management that ensures the quality of service. There are still plenty rooms for improving QoS in IoT using traffic classification methods.

div.head: Scalability
div.p: IoT is well known for its huge scale deployment. Such a huge scale generates enormous data not only in a large volume, but also in various forms, values, velocity, and veracity which implies the definition of Gig Data [155]. The bid data generated by sensors, actuators, IoT gadgets, smartphones and more are converted to a network packet that are further deeply analysed. An example of the challenge caused by this huge scale of data is the prediction of possible intrusion attacks. Essentially, the efficient functioning of a NIDS highly depends on the continuous collection of traffic data and learning their characteristics on the fly. However, the continuous collection of Big Data will lead to significant system challenges to implementing machine learning frameworks. Currently, there are a number of tools such as Hadoop, Spark, and more, that lighten the process of Big Data analysis. However, these tools require a scalable environment to run the machine learning frameworks and the process of data analysis in a real-time manner.

div.head: Standardization
div.p: IoT involves many technologies across multiple industries. The number of IoT devices including M2M and non-M2M devices are increasing in an exponential fashion. For example, a small home network may contain more than a hundred connected IoT devices. Hence, standardization of IoT devices and protocols is of significant importance. The scope of standardization ranges from communicating layer standard organization (i.e. ISTF, IEEE) to application layer standardization (i.e. ETSI, CoRE). These standards not only profit from organizations and vendors, but also many applications and services such as network traffic classification benefit from them. For example, IETF is motivating vendors to develop formal specifications of the intended purpose of their IoT devices, in the form of a Manufacturer Usage Description (MUD), so that their network behaviour in any operating environment can be locked down and verified rigorously [84]. Therefore, a fast and universal standard realization is highly required in order to develop a globally agreed and common end-to-end specification for realizing both use cases and architecture principles of IoT.

div.head: Up-to-date traffic pattern
div.p: A periodic update of traffic patterns is highly required for specific applications in IoT traffic classification. For example, an IDS classifies network traffic through observing the network traffic to detect any abnormality in the traffic patterns. The process of periodically updating traffic patterns is significant in terms of detecting malicious traffic. This is because some illegitimate traffic is able to take control of new masks in a short while; therefore, traffic pattern update needs to be done swiftly [156]. The same issue is feasible for other scenarios such as smart homes/ factories, water supply systems attacks, etc. User authentication model is also at risk using IoT traffic classification where a fake user can mask the traffic signature of the original user.

div.head: Open Issues
div.p: Although traffic classification has been widely accepted as a pervasive practice in many organisations and applications, it is still immature in IoT domain. There are several existing issues that are yet to be opened which cause more challenges continue to emerge. In this section, some of the open research issues are addressed.

div.head: Smart Home IoT vulnerabilities
div.p: IoT devices are seen as a possible target or source of multiple types of cyber-attacks [157]. An important security challenge is the accessibility of information as well as the availability of the resource for communication. However, accessibility and availability can be disturbed by attacks such as DDoS.

IoT devices can be grouped into two categories based on the management of the smart home environment [158]. The first group is locally managed devices which comprises the devices that connected to a local network. These devices are accessible within their native network where the smart home device resides. The second one is the remotely managed devices in which the devices are connected to the Internet of an external network. As these devices can be accessed from the Internet, the risks associated with the Internet are also increasing. Security vulnerabilities in smart home devices not only attract hackers to disturb the functionality of these devices, but also motivate them to hijack and use devices as the DDOS botnet in a large-scale network. An example is the Mirai botnet attack in 2016 that took advantage of those unprotected IoT devices by scanning the internet for open telnet port with default usernames and passwords to access and succeed to control more than a hundred thousand of IoT devices. Those infected devices are later used to generate DDoS traffic attacking the targeted victim. In this regard, novel solutions are needed to reduce the number of devices without such security that could potentially lead to more dangerous attacks like Mirai in the future. A better understanding of the nature and characteristics of the traffic generated by smart home IoT device is necessary for early detection and prevention against an attack generated by such devices. Currently, there are no researches aimed at identifying characteristics of exclusively MTC traffic that generate smart home IoT devices.

div.head: Smart City
div.p: The study in [53] reported that smart cities traffic data is more challenging compared to smart home or industry IoT applications. First, the data traffic scale is bigger because there are larger numbers of users and IoT devices. Second, with a variety of services offered, data flows transferred between devices become more diverse. Third, traffic attacks come from many sources and with more complex malware traffic that uses the obfuscation technique to make them be invisible. All these reasons include the complexity of data traffic and the differences in fine details of smart cities, which impose a major challenge on the classification of traffic in various scenarios. However, to date, no specific data from smart city traffic is publicly available for the purpose of understanding the characteristics and a real-world case study. Thus, a dataset of the traffic trace of smart city without neglecting any area must be developed that covers all the perspectives in smart city characteristics.

div.head: IoT traffic classification
div.p: It is comprehended that IoT traffic nowadays comprises various types of behaviour such as communication types, events, source, pattern, shapes, loads, volumes, etc. Different from the past, M2M devices are not limited to small sensor communications. In fact, IoT includes every object with communication functionality and connectivity. Even newly in the case of generated traffic by M2M devices, the variance of the number of sessions that are started every day is seen extremely higher than in smartphones [12]. This indicates a significant impact on traffic patterns as well as management and control. Thus, the behaviour of M2M can generate different characteristics, depending on the number and type of devices that are active in the network. With this consideration, one would take a precise set of traffic features of IoT to design a robust and reliable solution that addresses specific demands such as security, analysis, discovery, energy-saving and QoS concerns. Besides, considering a necessary set of objectives such as self-adaptability, cost-efficiency, and hardware independency, new researches and further solutions is required.

div.head: Dataset
div.p: Traffic source is an essential part of a study's evaluation in terms of effectiveness and performance. Current public datasets are mostly provided for conventional networks with a shallow consideration toward specific features or infrastructures. Recently, the domain of traffic classification studies in IoT has dramatically increased. Studies are targeting specific objectives, new features, and different characteristics. Generally, publishing a real traffic trace can reveal security policies and privacy issues of users and organisations. As a result, a vast portion of the studies implemented either an out-dated dataset or a synthetic dataset generated by a lab testbed/incomprehensive use case. Therefore, finding a valid dataset that specifically targets an IoT domain is quite bothersome if not impossible.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This paper surveyed recent works in the field of traffic classification in the IoT domain. With the emergence of the IoT concept, various types of devices are being connected to each other. IoT devices compromise a wide range of diversities in types including portable, static, implantable, wearable devices etc. Motivated by the rise of new traffic patterns and the diversity in MTM/HTC characteristics, it is understood that IoT traffic nature is dissimilar to the conventional network traffic. Therefore, traffic classification in the IoT domain is more challenging in comparison with non-IoT domain. This is because, in IoT domain, the diversity of devices and its heterogeneity are extremely higher than in the non-IoT domain. Although the main concerns in traffic classification are security and QoS issues, new concerns and domains are newly emerging such as smart cities and even low-cost communication in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN). In this paper, we discussed the characteristics of the IoT network traffic and distinguished it from the human traffic patterns. A light-weight overview of traffic classification models was presented for a smooth transition to IoT traffic classification. We presented a comprehensive review of the current state-of-the-art IoT traffic classification in the context of application and architecture in IoT. From the review, it is understood that the major focus of the studies in IoT traffic classification is toward security concerns. Finally, we highlighted current challenges and possible future direction in IoT traffic network traffic classification. It is worth mentioning here that traffic classification research in IoT is still in its infancy stage and is yet to be tested in a real environment under realistic evaluations and datasets. Developing a dataset from real-world use cases and devices is highly required to maturase and realising traffic classification researches in IoT.
